definitions.definition: to make something go or be taken to a place, especially by post, email, radio, etc.
definitions.sensetop: send somethingsend something to somebody/somethingsend somebody somethingsend something back

examples.text: She **sent a letter** of support.
Let me just **send** this **email**.
to **send** something **by post**
to **send** something **by mail**
I sent the package by airmail.
Users were unable to **send or receive** emails for two days.
Have you sent a Christmas card to your mother yet?
A radio **signal was sent** to the spacecraft.
Have you sent your mother a Christmas card yet?
I'll **send you a** text **message**.
Can you send me a link to the website?
He sent me a copy of his new book.
The laptop was faulty so I sent it back to the manufacturers.

definitions.definition: to tell somebody something by sending them a message
definitions.sensetop: send somethingsend something to somebodysend somebody somethingsend something (that)…send to do something

examples.text: My parents **send their love**.
Henry sent his regards to you.
What sort of **message** is that **sending** to young people?
He **sent** me **word** to come.
She **sent word** (that) she could not come.
She sent to say that she was coming home.

definitions.definition: to tell somebody to go somewhere or to do something; to arrange for somebody to go somewhere
definitions.sensetop: send somebodysend somebody + adv./prep.send somebody to do something

examples.text: Ed couldn't make it so they sent me instead.
She sent the kids to bed early.
The judge **sent her to prison** for two years.
He was **sent** away **to** boarding **school** at the age of eight.
The government has agreed to **send** 3 000 **troops** to the region.
We are being sent on a training course next month.
Children were **sent home** from school because it was just too hot.
I've sent Tom to buy some milk.

definitions.definition: to make something/somebody move quickly or suddenly
definitions.sensetop: send something/somebody doing somethingsend something/somebody + adv./prep.

examples.text: Every step he took sent the pain shooting up his leg.
The punch **sent him flying**.
The report sent share prices down a further 8p.

definitions.definition: to make somebody behave or react in a particular way
definitions.sensetop: send somebody to somethingsend somebody into somethingsend somebody + adj.

examples.text: Her music always sends me to sleep.
Her account of the visit sent us into fits of laughter.
All the publicity nearly sent him crazy.

definitions.definition: to tell somebody clearly or rudely to go away

examples.text: She tried to interfere but I sent her packing.

definitions.definition: used to say that you should accept an unpleasant situation or event because you cannot change it

wordOrigin: Old English sendan, of Germanic origin; related to Dutch zenden and German senden.
